taxon_name.authority: G. Don in J. C. Loudon

taxon_identification.taxon_hierarchy: family cyperaceae;genus carex;section glareosae;species canescens;subspecies disjuncta

bio:treatment.description: Culms 30–90 cm. Inflorescences 6–12(–15) cm, all but distalmost spikes distant, proximal 2 spikes 2–5 cm apart. 2n = 54.
Wet, usually base-poor habitats, such as sphagnum bogs, moist coniferous forests and meadows, from lowlands to near the timberline in mountains;
St. Pierre and Miquelon; N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.S., Ont., P.E.I., Que.; Conn., Del., D.C., Ill., Ind., Maine, Md., Mass., Mich., Minn., N.H., N.J., N.Y., N.C., Ohio, Pa., R.I., S.C., Vt., Va., Wis.
bio:treatment.discussion: Carex canescens subsp. disjuncta is a dominating subspecies in the southern part of the range of the species in eastern North America; it grades into subsp. canescens in northern areas. Subspecies disjuncta differs from subsp. canescens in its longer culms (to 90 cm), leaves, inflorescences [1–12(–15) cm], and spikes. The subglobular spikes are often more numerous and the proximal separated by 2–5 cm. The perigynia are slightly longer, clearly wider and more abruptly beaked than in the type subspecies.
